text: I. How Brigadier Gerard Lost His Ear
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: It was the old Brigadier who was talking in the cafe.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I have seen a great many cities, my friends. I would not dare to tell
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: you how many I have entered as a conqueror with eight hundred of my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: little fighting devils clanking and jingling behind me. The cavalry were
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: in front of the Grande Armee, and the Hussars of Conflans were in front
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of the cavalry, and I was in front of the Hussars. But of all the cities
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: which we visited Venice is the most ill-built and ridiculous. I cannot
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: imagine how the people who laid it out thought that the cavalry could
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: manoeuvre. It would puzzle Murat or Lassalle to bring a squadron into
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: that square of theirs. For this reason we left Kellermann's heavy
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: brigade and also my own Hussars at Padua on the mainland. But
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Suchet with the infantry held the town, and he had chosen me as his
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: aide-de-camp for that winter, because he was pleased about the affair
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of the Italian fencing-master at Milan. The fellow was a good swordsman,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and it was fortunate for the credit of French arms that it was I who was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: opposed to him. Besides, he deserved a lesson, for if one does not like
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: a prima donna's singing one can always be silent, but it is intolerable
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: that a public affront should be put upon a pretty woman. So the sympathy
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: was all with me, and after the affair had blown over and the man's widow
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: had been pensioned Suchet chose me as his own galloper, and I followed
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: him to Venice, where I had the strange adventure which I am about to
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: tell you.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: You have not been to Venice? No, for it is seldom that the French
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: travel. We were great travellers in those days. From Moscow to Cairo
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: we had travelled everywhere, but we went in larger parties than were
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: convenient to those whom we visited, and we carried our passports in
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: our limbers. It will be a bad day for Europe when the French start
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: travelling again, for they are slow to leave their homes, but when they
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: have done so no one can say how far they will go if they have a guide
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: like our little man to point out the way. But the great days are gone
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and the great men are dead, and here am I, the last of them, drinking
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: wine of Suresnes and telling old tales in a cafe.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: But it is of Venice that I would speak. The folk there live like
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: water-rats upon a mud-bank, but the houses are very fine, and the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: churches, especially that of St. Mark, are as great as any I have seen.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: But above all they are proud of their statues and their pictures, which
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: are the most famous in Europe. There are many soldiers who think that
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: because one's trade is to make war one should never have a thought above
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: fighting and plunder. There was old Bouvet, for example--the one who was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: killed by the Prussians on the day that I won the Emperor's medal; if
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: you took him away from the camp and the canteen, and spoke to him of
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: books or of art, he would sit and stare at you. But the highest soldier
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: is a man like myself who can understand the things of the mind and the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: soul. It is true that I was very young when I joined the army, and that
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the quarter-master was my only teacher, but if you go about the world
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: with your eyes open you cannot help learning a great deal.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Thus I was able to admire the pictures in Venice, and to know the names
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of the great men, Michael Titiens, and Angelus, and the others, who had
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: painted them. No one can say that Napoleon did not admire them also, for
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the very first thing which he did when he captured the town was to send
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the best of them to Paris. We all took what we could get, and I had two
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: pictures for my share.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: One of them, called "Nymphs Surprised," I kept for myself, and the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: other, "Saint Barbara," I sent as a present for my mother.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: It must be confessed, however, that some of our men behaved very badly
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: in this matter of the statues and the pictures. The people at Venice
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: were very much attached to them, and as to the four bronze horses which
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: stood over the gate of their great church, they loved them as dearly as
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: if they had been their children. I have always been a judge of a horse,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and I had a good look at these ones, but I could not see that there was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: much to be said for them. They were too coarse-limbed for light cavalry
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: charges and they had not the weight for the gun-teams.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: However, they were the only four horses, alive or dead, in the whole
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: town, so it was not to be expected that the people would know any
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: better. They wept bitterly when they were sent away, and ten French
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: soldiers were found floating in the canals that night. As a punishment
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: for these murders a great many more of their pictures were sent away,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and the soldiers took to breaking the statues and firing their muskets
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: at the stained-glass windows.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: This made the people furious, and there was very bad feeling in the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: town. Many officers and men disappeared during that winter, and even
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: their bodies were never found.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: For myself I had plenty to do, and I never found the time heavy on
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: my hands. In every country it has been my custom to try to learn the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: language. For this reason I always look round for some lady who will be
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: kind enough to teach it to me, and then we practise it together. This
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: is the most interesting way of picking it up, and before I was thirty I
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: could speak nearly every tongue in Europe; but it must be confessed that
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: what you learn is not of much use for the ordinary purposes of life. My
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: business, for example, has usually been with soldiers and peasants, and
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: what advantage is it to be able to say to them that I love only them,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and that I will come back when the wars are over?
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Never have I had so sweet a teacher as in Venice. Lucia was her first
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: name, and her second--but a gentleman forgets second names. I can say
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: this with all discretion, that she was of one of the senatorial families
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of Venice and that her grandfather had been Doge of the town.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: She was of an exquisite beauty--and when I, Etienne Gerard, use such a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: word as "exquisite," my friends, it has a meaning. I have judgment, I
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: have memories, I have the means of comparison. Of all the women who have
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: loved me there are not twenty to whom I could apply such a term as that.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: But I say again that Lucia was exquisite.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Of the dark type I do not recall her equal unless it were Dolores of
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Toledo. There was a little brunette whom I loved at Santarem when I was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: soldiering under Massena in Portugal--her name has escaped me. She was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of a perfect beauty, but she had not the figure nor the grace of Lucia.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: There was Agnes also. I could not put one before the other, but I do
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: none an injustice when I say that Lucia was the equal of the best.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: It was over this matter of pictures that I had first met her, for her
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: father owned a palace on the farther side of the Rialto Bridge upon the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Grand Canal, and it was so packed with wall-paintings that Suchet sent a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: party of sappers to cut some of them out and send them to Paris.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I had gone down with them, and after I had seen Lucia in tears it
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: appeared to me that the plaster would crack if it were taken from the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: support of the wall. I said so, and the sappers were withdrawn. After
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: that I was the friend of the family, and many a flask of Chianti have
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I cracked with the father and many a sweet lesson have I had from the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: daughter. Some of our French officers married in Venice that winter,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and I might have done the same, for I loved her with all my heart; but
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Etienne Gerard has his sword, his horse, his regiment, his mother, his
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Emperor, and his career. A debonair Hussar has room in his life for
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: love, but none for a wife. So I thought then, my friends, but I did not
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: see the lonely days when I should long to clasp those vanished hands,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and turn my head away when I saw old comrades with their tall children
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: standing round their chairs. This love which I had thought was a joke
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and a plaything--it is only now that I understand that it is the moulder
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of one's life, the most solemn and sacred of all things--Thank you, my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: friend, thank you! It is a good wine, and a second bottle cannot hurt.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: And now I will tell you how my love for Lucia was the cause of one
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of the most terrible of all the wonderful adventures which have ever
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: befallen me, and how it was that I came to lose the top of my right ear.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: You have often asked me why it was missing. To-night for the first time
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I will tell you.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Suchet's head-quarters at that time was the old palace of the Doge
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Dandolo, which stands on the lagoon not far from the place of San Marco.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: It was near the end of the winter, and I had returned one night from the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Theatre Goldini, when I found a note from Lucia and a gondola waiting.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: She prayed me to come to her at once as she was in trouble. To a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Frenchman and a soldier there was but one answer to such a note. In an
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: instant I was in the boat and the gondolier was pushing out into the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: dark lagoon.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I remember that as I took my seat in the boat I was struck by the man's
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: great size. He was not tall, but he was one of the broadest men that
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I have ever seen in my life. But the gondoliers of Venice are a strong
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: breed, and powerful men are common enough among them. The fellow took
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: his place behind me and began to row.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: A good soldier in an enemy's country should everywhere and at all times
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: be on the alert. It has been one of the rules of my life, and if I have
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: lived to wear grey hairs it is because I have observed it. And yet upon
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: that night I was as careless as a foolish young recruit who fears lest
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: he should be thought to be afraid. My pistols I had left behind in my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: hurry. My sword was at my belt, but it is not always the most convenient
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of weapons. I lay back in my seat in the gondola, lulled by the gentle
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: swish of the water and the steady creaking of the oar. Our way lay
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: through a network of narrow canals with high houses towering on either
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: side and a thin slit of star-spangled sky above us. Here and there, on
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the bridges which spanned the canal, there was the dim glimmer of an oil
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: lamp, and sometimes there came a gleam from some niche where a candle
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: burned before the image of a saint. But save for this it was all black,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and one could only see the water by the white fringe which curled round
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the long black nose of our boat. It was a place and a time for dreaming.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I thought of my own past life, of all the great deeds in which I had
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: been concerned, of the horses that I had handled, and of the women that
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I had loved. Then I thought also of my dear mother, and I fancied her
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: joy when she heard the folk in the village talking about the fame of her
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: son. Of the Emperor also I thought, and of France, the dear fatherland,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the sunny France, mother of beautiful daughters and of gallant sons. My
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: heart glowed within me as I thought of how we had brought her colours
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: so many hundred leagues beyond her borders. To her greatness I would
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: dedicate my life. I placed my hand upon my heart as I swore it, and at
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: that instant the gondolier fell upon me from behind.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: When I say that he fell upon me I do not mean merely that he attacked
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: me, but that he really did tumble upon me with all his weight. The
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: fellow stands behind you and above you as he rows, so that you can
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: neither see him nor can you in any way guard against such an assault.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: One moment I had sat with my mind filled with sublime resolutions, the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: next I was flattened out upon the bottom of the boat, the breath dashed
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: out of my body, and this monster pinning me down. I felt the fierce
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: pants of his hot breath upon the back of my neck. In an instant he had
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: torn away my sword, had slipped a sack over my head, and had tied a rope
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: firmly round the outside of it.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: There I was at the bottom of the gondola as helpless as a trussed fowl.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I could not shout, I could not move; I was a mere bundle. An instant
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: later I heard once more the swishing of the water and the creaking of
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the oar.

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: headquarters when he came out and stood motionless for half an hour,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: his arms folded upon his breast, staring through the darkness toward the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: east.

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: was looking for I could not imagine; but at last he gave a bitter curse,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and, turning on his heel, he went back into the house, banging the door
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: behind him.

text: Next day the second aide-de-camp, Duplessis, had an interview with
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: again. That night, as I sat in the ante-room, the Marshal passed me,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and I observed him through the window standing and staring to the east
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: exactly as he had done before. For fully half an hour he remained there,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: a black shadow in the gloom.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: my head, but he did not send for me, and I knew him too well to go
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: unsought.

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Next morning it was my turn, for I was the only aide-de-camp left. I
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: was his favourite aide-de-camp. His heart went out always to a smart
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: he sent for me that morning.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "Gerard," said he. "Come here!"
title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and beyond that the lines of the cavalry with the long rows of picketed
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: horses.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: We could see the French outposts, and then a stretch of open country,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: intersected by vineyards. A range of hills lay beyond, with one
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard

text: rising until it passed through a gap in the hills.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "This," said Massena, pointing to the mountain, "is the Sierra de
title: The Adventures of Gerard

text: Merodal. Do you perceive anything upon the top?"
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I answered that I did not.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "Now?" he asked, and he handed me his field-glass.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: With its aid I perceived a small mound or cairn upon the crest.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: there as a beacon. We laid it when the country was in our hands, and
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: now, although we no longer hold it, the beacon remains undisturbed.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Gerard, that beacon must be lit to-night. France needs it, the Emperor
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: needs it, the army needs it. Two of your comrades have gone to light it,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: but neither has made his way to the summit. To-day it is your turn, and
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I pray that you may have better luck."
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: It is not for a soldier to ask the reason for his orders, and so I was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: about to hurry from the room, but the Marshal laid his hand upon my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: shoulder and held me.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "You shall know all, and so learn how high is the cause for which you
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: risk your life," said he. "Fifty miles to the south of us, on the other
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: side of the Tagus, is the army of General Clausel. His camp is situated
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: near a peak named the Sierra d'Ossa. On the summit of this peak is a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: beacon, and by this beacon he has a picket. It is agreed between us that
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: when at midnight he shall see our signal-fire he shall light his own as
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: an answer, and shall then at once fall back upon the main army. If
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: he does not start at once I must go without him. For two days I have
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: endeavoured to send him his message. It must reach him to-day, or his
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: army will be left behind and destroyed."
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Ah, my friends, how my heart swelled when I heard how high was the task
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: which Fortune had assigned to me!
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: If my life were spared, here was one more splendid new leaf for my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: laurel crown. If, on the other hand, I died, then it would be a death
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: worthy of such a career. I said nothing, but I cannot doubt that all
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the noble thoughts that were in me shone in my face, for Massena took my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: hand and wrung it.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "There is the hill and there the beacon," said he.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "There is only this guerilla and his men between you and it. I cannot
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: detach a large party for the enterprise and a small one would be seen
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and destroyed. Therefore to you alone I commit it. Carry it out in your
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: own way, but at twelve o'clock this night let me see the fire upon the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: hill."
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: "If it is not there," said I, "then I pray you, Marshal Massena, to see
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: that my effects are sold and the money sent to my mother." So I raised
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: my hand to my busby and turned upon my heel, my heart glowing at the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: thought of the great exploit which lay before me.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: I sat in my own chamber for some little time considering how I had best
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: take the matter in hand. The fact that neither Cortex nor Duplessis,
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: who were very zealous and active officers, had succeeded in reaching
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the summit of the Sierra de Merodal, showed that the country was very
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: closely watched by the guerillas. I reckoned out the distance upon a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: map. There were ten miles of open country to be crossed before reaching
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the hills. Then came a belt of forest on the lower slopes of the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: mountain, which may have been three or four miles wide. And then there
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: was the actual peak itself, of no very great height, but without any
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: cover to conceal me. Those were the three stages of my journey.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: It seemed to me that once I had reached the shelter of the wood all
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: would be easy, for I could lie concealed within its shadows and climb
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: upward under the cover of night.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: From eight till twelve would give me four hours of darkness in which
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: to make the ascent. It was only the first stage, then, which I had
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: seriously to consider.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Over that flat country there lay the inviting white road, and I
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: remembered that my comrades had both taken their horses. That was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: clearly their ruin, for nothing could be easier than for the brigands to
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: keep watch upon the road, and to lay an ambush for all who passed along
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: it. It would not be difficult for me to ride across country, and I was
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: well horsed at that time, for I had not only Violette and Rataplan, who
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: thought, I determined to go upon foot, since I should then be in a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: better state to take advantage of any chance which might offer. As to my
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: dress, I covered my Hussar uniform with a long cloak, and I put a
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: grey forage cap upon my head. You may ask me why I did not dress as
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: a peasant, but I answer that a man of honour has no desire to die the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: death of a spy. It is one thing to be murdered, and it is another to be
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: justly executed by the laws of war. I would not run the risk of such an
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: end.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: In the late afternoon I stole out of the camp and passed through the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: line of our pickets. Beneath my cloak I had a field-glass and a pocket
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: pistol, as well as my sword. In my pocket were tinder, flint, and steel.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: For two or three miles I kept under cover of the vineyards, and made
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: such good progress that my heart was high within me, and I thought to
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: myself that it only needed a man of some brains to take the matter in
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: hand to bring it easily to success. Of course, Cortex and Duplessis
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: galloping down the high-road would be easily seen, but the intelligent
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: had got as far as five miles before I met any check. At that point there
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: is a small wine-house, round which I perceived some carts and a number
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of people, the first that I had seen. Now that I was well outside the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: lines I knew that every person was my enemy, so I crouched lower while I
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: going on. I then perceived that these people were peasants, who were
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: loading two waggons with empty wine-casks. I failed to see how they
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: could either help or hinder me, so I continued upon my way.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: discipline which was practised by this scoundrel whom they called "The
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Smiler," and this, no doubt, was an example of it.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: Between the hills there was a cordon of sentries, and though I worked
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: some distance round to the flank I still found myself faced by the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: enemy. It was a puzzle what to do.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: There was so little cover that a rat could hardly cross without being
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: seen. Of course, it would be easy enough to slip through at night, as I
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: more dangerous than the last. And then suddenly I had that flash of
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: light which comes to the brave man who refuses to despair.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: You remember I have mentioned that two waggons were loading up with
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: and it was evident that those waggons were going in the direction which
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: of delight as it crossed my mind, and I hurried away instantly in the
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: direction of the inn. There, from behind some bushes, I had a good look
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: at what was going on upon the road.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard

text: they had completed one waggon and the lower tier of the other. A number

text: resist a dashing young Hussar. As I watched, the three fellows went into
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: the inn, for the day was hot and they were thirsty after their labour.
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: waggon, and crept into one of the empty casks.
title: The Adventures of Gerard

text: inward. There I crouched like a dog in its kennel, my knees drawn up to

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: within my barrel chuckled at every step, for it was carrying me whither

title: The Adventures of Gerard

text: waggons.

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: The waggon stopped suddenly with a jerk, and I heard a number of gruff
title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: voices in excited talk. "Where, where?" cried one. "On our cart," said
title: The Adventures of Gerard

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

text: What a situation, my friends, for a man of my standing!

author: Doyle, Arthur Conan

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard

title: The Adventures of Gerard
